page.title: 13BEE KEEPING IN SHILLINGSTONE
page.content: Bee keeping must have been practised in Shillingstone since the time of the Eschelling family at least. The number of orchards in the past and the lush natural flora has made these riverside pastures a rich source of nectar. There are two apiarists in Shillingstone. Cecil Trent and his sons have a number of colonies at the southern end of the village and Clive Edwards, a beekeeper for 20 years, has hives on apple blossom, lime blossom, chalk flora and bluebell woods. He also imports lavender honey from Provence. Modern agriculture and the grubbing out of the old cider orchards has greatly depleted the nectar.
